title: CBL1: Brachial Plexus and Its Major Branches, Nerve Injuries

questions.question: 1. Which spinal nerve roots form the brachial plexus?
2. What is the correct order of subdivisions in the brachial plexus?
3. The union of the C5 and C6 roots forms which trunk of the brachial plexus?
4. Injury to the upper trunk of the brachial plexus typically leads to which condition?
5. Klumpke's palsy is most commonly associated with damage to which part of the brachial plexus?
6. Which nerve, arising from the lateral cord, is primarily responsible for innervating the flexor muscles of the anterior arm?
7. Which nerve is most commonly injured in midshaft humeral fractures?
8. Injury to the axillary nerve can lead to paralysis of which muscle?
9. The median nerve is formed by contributions from which cords of the brachial plexus?
10. Which nerve provides sensory innervation to the lateral aspect of the forearm?
11. Which nerve primarily innervates the intrinsic muscles of the hand, contributing to fine motor control?
12. A patient with wrist drop most likely has an injury to which nerve?
13. An ulnar nerve injury may lead to which characteristic hand deformity?
14. Which nerve injury is associated with a winged scapula?
15. The medial cord of the brachial plexus primarily contributes to which major nerve?
16. During difficult childbirth, a traction injury to the brachial plexus often results in Erb-Duchenne palsy. Which of the following is a common clinical presentation of this injury?
options: Arm adducted and internally rotated with extended elbow
Arm abducted and externally rotated with flexed elbow
